explanation:
_MHD_DROP_CONST: The function uses (fd_set *) _MHD_DROP_CONST(read_fd_set) to cast away const. You must inspect the macro definition to see how const is being removed and whether that cast is justified or a MISRA violation.

FD_ISSET / fd_set (system headers): FD_ISSET takes a non-const fd_set * (typical POSIX signature). You need the fd_set type and FD_ISSET prototype to confirm whether the implementation requires a non-const pointer and thus forces a const-drop (potential MISRA issue).

MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_: This macro is used to decide whether FD_ISSET can be used. Its definition/parameter types determine whether it operates on const or non-const fd_set pointers (or none at all) and therefore affects whether const pointers are being unnecessarily downgraded.

MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_, MHD_itc_r_fd_, MHD_itc_clear_: These ITC helpers are used before FD_ISSET on the ITC fd. Their prototypes/types reveal whether they take or return pointers that should be const-qualified; they also explain why the code manipulates the ITC and whether any const-casting is needed there.

struct MHD_Daemon (type definition): The daemon pointer is passed into many helpers and some fields are modified (e.g. data_already_pending). You must see the structure to confirm which members are modified vs only read so you can judge whether any of those pointers/fields could have been const.

struct MHD_Connection (type definition): The function traverses and reads/writes members of MHD_Connection (socket_fd, sk_nonblck, prev) and passes the connection object to call_handlers. The struct definition is required to decide whether connections could be pointed-to by const pointers or why non-const is required.

urh_from_fdset (prototype): In the HTTPS/upgrade block the code passes read_fd_set/write_fd_set/except_fd_set (const fd_set *) directly to urh_from_fdset. Its prototype tells whether it accepts const fd_set * (no cast) or non-const (would require similar const-dropping) and thus if the code consistently respects pointer constness.

Together these symbols let you determine where const is intentionally or inadvertently removed, whether casts are necessary because of underlying API signatures, and whether pointer parameters or local pointers could/should be const-qualified under MISRA C guidance.
